sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,The Cottage., in Poetical Essays, (Glasgow, 1788), 178-180.

head.title: The Cottage.11 First published in Poetical Essays, (1788), pp. 178-180; revised for Poems (1794); reprinted in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 8, 1796). This is one of the only poems to which Turnbull made substantive revisions. The text presented here takes its copytext from 1788 and incorporates into it Turnbull's revision at line 18 and the additional stanza, stanza V, also from 1794. David Radcliffe suggests that this poem’s treatment of rural life is in the tradition of Shenstone's School-Mistress, but it also alludes more generally to Robert Fergusson, “The Farmer's Ingle,” and Robert Burns, “The Cottar's Saturday Night” (Spenser and the Tradition).

l.emph: Hail lowly roofs, where pure contentment dwells.
l.note: 2 Unattributed. Cf. “Where hermit peace with mild contentment dwells”: William Julius Mickle, Liberty: An Elegy to the Memory of his Royal Highness Frederic, late Prince of Wales, line 48 [English Poetry Database from Mickle, Poetical Works (1806)]; and “And rural huts, where sweet contentment dwells”: Edward Ward, Honesty in Distress, but reliev’d by no Party, Act 1, line 2 [English Poetry Database, from Ward, Miscellaneous Writings, III (1712)]. Not in94.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Within the windings of yon woody dale,33 yon woody 88] a woody 94
Beside a burnie,44 n. small brook. on a bonny green,
Where raws of whitening hawthorns scent the gale,
A wee bit canty55 adj. cheerful. theicket house is seen;
Fu' snug it stands frae angry winds, I ween,
Around, the stacks in rising cones appear,
Which shaw the owner thrifty is and bien,66 adj. comfortable.
Nae pride has he, nor heaps of worthless geer,
But routh77 n. plenty. o' kintra88 o' kintra 88] of country 94 fare, the winter days to cheer.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Here stands the bar, to hoord99 to hoord 88] that hoards 94 the ripen'd grain,
With lowly roof, of strae and divets made,
Where aft the farmer wheels, with might and main,
The whirling flail, and nae ignoble trade:
And there the milk-house, where the dairy maid
Aft skims the boyns,1010 n. milk-pan. and presses out the whey;
And here a place, where carts and pleughs are laid;
And there the stable, for the horse and kye;

And here the hen-house stands, and there the grumphies'1111 the grumphies' sty 94] the stinking stye 88. grumphies' n. pigs'. In 1788, this line read "And here the hen-house stands, and there the stinking stye." stye.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Into the ha' house if ye chance to keek,
Ye'll tent the ingle1212 n. fire burning on a hearth. blinkin bonnily,
The crazy rafters, painted o'er wi' reek;1313 n. smoke.
A twa-arm'd chair within the neuk1414 n. corner, recess. ye'll see,
Where aft the guidman leans, wi' meikle glee,
And smoaks his pipe, and tells his pawky1515 adj. wily. tale;
An antic ambry,1616 antic ambry 88] antique am'rie 94. n. cupboard. made of aiken tree,
Wi' caps and luggies, rang'd upon a dale,
And meikle toop-horn spoons, and plates to haud1717 haud 88] had 94 misprint the kail.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Ben i' the spence, for parlour hae they nane,
The wa's are brawly whiten'd o'er wi' lime;
A polish'd chimla, and a clean hearth-stane;
A curtain'd bed, and eke a cupboard prime:
The house contains nae mae fligairy things,
(For luxury is sure an unco crime)
Yet, frae this little wealth, contentment springs,
And thro' the roof, the voice of discord never rings.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Ye, who in lordly halls and bow'rs abide,
And at who's nod obsequious menials bend,
May boast your gay attire and gilded pride,
And rant and roar, and many thousands spend.
But cou'd your haughty minds once condescend
To leave a while the formulas of state,
Ye'd see sweet peace and happiness attend
The humble cot, and at an easy rate,
More real joy and bless the simple swains await.1919 added 94] not in 88
